title: John Bercow tells Brexiteers 'It's bad form to blame the referee'
text:

John Bercow took aim at hardline Brexiteers who have accused him of bias while looking back on his time as Speaker ahead of his resignation at the end of this month.

He has described bitter Brexit debates in the House of Commons as being among the worst he has seen in his 22 years as an MP for Buckingham.

Mr Bercow dismissed what he called ‘downmarket attacks on Parliament’ and said some of the insults hurled at MPs in debates were ‘low grade and vulgar’.

On the accusations made against him by those claiming he favours the opinions of Remainers, Mr Bercow said: ‘If you are losing the match, it’s quite bad form to blame the referee.’

In a wide-ranging interview with CNN, he said he was ‘entirely unmoved by some of the more downmarket attacks on Parliament that have been launched in recent times.

‘They are unworthy, they don’t amount to a row of beans and I’m not intimidated by them.’

John Bercow has said he will resign as Speaker on 31 October (Picture: Reuters)

He added: ‘I wouldn’t say I’m a remainer enabler. I would say that I’m an enabler of all colleagues across the House who want to express their different points of view.

‘I thought the Brexiteers were in favour of taking back control of Parliament being in the driving seat?

‘Well, they can’t have it both ways.’

Mr Bercow, who has said he will stand down as Speaker on 31 October, called the European Union (Withdrawal) (No.2) Act – known as the Benn Act – ‘the most logical consequence if a deal isn’t agreed’.

Boris Johnson previously labelled it the ‘surrender bill’.

Later in the interview, he came close to tears as he reflected on murdered MP Jo Cox.

The Buckingham MP was shown a video clip of him paying tribute to Ms Cox in the Commons following her death in 2016.

He said: ‘Any death in such awful circumstances is an outrage and a tragedy.

‘Yet this death, in this manner, of this person, our democratically elected colleague Jo Cox is particularly shocking and repugnant.’

Fighting back tears, Mr Bercow told CNN that he remembered the moment ‘very keenly’ and ‘the sentiment is very raw’.

He said: ‘Really, Jo was a great exponent of that principle of political difference, personal amiability.

‘It should be possible for us as democrats to disagree agreeably.’

Ms Cox died on 16 June, 2016, after she was shot and stabbed multiple times by far-right sympathiser Thomas Mair in her constituency of Batley and Spen, West Yorkshire.
